texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This blog moved from Wordpress to Hugo back in 2020 and that was a great decision. Static blog generators free you from the vast majority of blog hosting security risks (but some still exist) and they give you the freedom to host your blog almost anywhere.
texts.text: This blog moved from Wordpress to Hugo back in 2020 and that was a great decision. Static blog generators free you from the vast majority of blog hosting security risks (but some still exist) and they give you the freedom to host your blog almost anywhere.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've tried a few hosting methods for the blog so far:
texts.text: I've tried a few hosting methods for the blog so far:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: On a VPS or on cloud instances
texts.text: On a VPS or on cloud instances

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: With a third party static hosting specialist, such as Netlify
texts.text: With a third party static hosting specialist, such as Netlify

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: In GitHub or GitLab Pages
texts.text: In GitHub or GitLab Pages

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Using CloudFlare Pages
texts.text: Using CloudFlare Pages

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Object storage with a CDN (Backblaze/CloudFlare)
texts.text: Object storage with a CDN (Backblaze/CloudFlare)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All of them have their advantages and disadvantages.
texts.text: All of them have their advantages and disadvantages.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For example, running on a VPS with a web server like nginx gives you a ton of control over every aspect of the site, but then there's a server to manage. GitHub pages provides a fast and free option for hosting a static blog from a git repository, but you give up lots of control and access to metrics.
texts.text: For example, running on a VPS with a web server like nginx gives you a ton of control over every aspect of the site, but then there's a server to manage. GitHub pages provides a fast and free option for hosting a static blog from a git repository, but you give up lots of control and access to metrics.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've been a bit leery of free offerings in the past because they can easily be taken away or they may suddenly begin charging for the service. Often times the free services turn  me  into the product.
texts.text: I've been a bit leery of free offerings in the past because they can easily be taken away or they may suddenly begin charging for the service. Often times the free services turn  me  into the product.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After hacking with  AWS CloudFront  this week at work, I set off on an expedition to see if I could host this blog with it.[^spoiler]
texts.text: After hacking with  AWS CloudFront  this week at work, I set off on an expedition to see if I could host this blog with it.[^spoiler]

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Architecture
texts.text: Architecture

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As with most cloud-related deployments, we stitch together a few different cloud services to make the magic happen. Here's the goal at a high level:
texts.text: As with most cloud-related deployments, we stitch together a few different cloud services to make the magic happen. Here's the goal at a high level:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GitHub Actions should build the blog content using Hugo and ship that content to a bucket in AWS S3.
texts.text: GitHub Actions should build the blog content using Hugo and ship that content to a bucket in AWS S3.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AWS CloudFront serves the content from the S3 bucket to visitors around the world.
texts.text: AWS CloudFront serves the content from the S3 bucket to visitors around the world.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Logs from website visitors are placed in a different S3 bucket.
texts.text: Logs from website visitors are placed in a different S3 bucket.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: How much does all of this cost? The first step for any AWS deployment involves a quick look at the  AWS Free Tier  list:
texts.text: How much does all of this cost? The first step for any AWS deployment involves a quick look at the  AWS Free Tier  list:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: IAM roles and policies are already free. 🎉
texts.text: IAM roles and policies are already free. 🎉

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AWS S3 gives you 5GB free for the first 12 months and then it's $0.023/GB/month after that.[^s3extras]
texts.text: AWS S3 gives you 5GB free for the first 12 months and then it's $0.023/GB/month after that.[^s3extras]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AWS CloudFront allows 1TB of data transfer and 10M requests per month.
texts.text: AWS CloudFront allows 1TB of data transfer and 10M requests per month.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: We're building our static content in GitHub Actions and that's free already.
texts.text: We're building our static content in GitHub Actions and that's free already.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My blog uses about 218MB of storage and transfers less than 1TB per month. My bill should easily come in under $1.
texts.text: My blog uses about 218MB of storage and transfers less than 1TB per month. My bill should easily come in under $1.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's get started.
texts.text: Let's get started.

texts.orig: Configure the storage
texts.text: Configure the storage

texts.orig: Our first stop on the blog hosting train is  AWS S3 . The S3 bucket holds the static files that make up the site. 🪣
texts.text: Our first stop on the blog hosting train is  AWS S3 . The S3 bucket holds the static files that make up the site. 🪣

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Getting certificates
texts.text: Getting certificates

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: AWS provides a domain validated certificates for free via AWS Certificate Manager (ACM). Once you make a certificate request, ACM provides you with a DNS record that must appear when ACM queries your domain name.
texts.text: AWS provides a domain validated certificates for free via AWS Certificate Manager (ACM). Once you make a certificate request, ACM provides you with a DNS record that must appear when ACM queries your domain name.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's request a certificate:
texts.text: Let's request a certificate:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go to the
texts.text: Go to the

texts.orig: Ensure
texts.text: Ensure

texts.orig: Provide the fully qualified domain name for your blog.
texts.text: Provide the fully qualified domain name for your blog.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now you should see your requested certificate in the list along with the  Pending validation  status. Click the certificate ID and take a look at the  Domains  section on the next page. You should see a  CNAME name  and  CNAME value  on the far right.
texts.text: Now you should see your requested certificate in the list along with the  Pending validation  status. Click the certificate ID and take a look at the  Domains  section on the next page. You should see a  CNAME name  and  CNAME value  on the far right.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Go to your DNS provider and create a DNS record that matches. ACM will query your domain using the  CNAME name  and it expects to see the  CNAME value  returned. Once the DNS record is in place, wait a minute or two for ACM to check the DNS record and flip the status to a green  Issued  status.
texts.text: Go to your DNS provider and create a DNS record that matches. ACM will query your domain using the  CNAME name  and it expects to see the  CNAME value  returned. Once the DNS record is in place, wait a minute or two for ACM to check the DNS record and flip the status to a green  Issued  status.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Go on to the next step once you see that green status on the certificate.
texts.text: Go on to the next step once you see that green status on the certificate.

texts.text: This is where we begin connecting some dots. CloudFront will serve content from the S3 bucket via a worldwide CDN and it uses the certificate we created in the last step.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At this point, we have a storage bucket ready to hold our content and a TLS-enabled CDN ready to serve the content. Now we need to build the content and ship it to S3.
texts.text: At this point, we have a storage bucket ready to hold our content and a TLS-enabled CDN ready to serve the content. Now we need to build the content and ship it to S3.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: GitHub Actions + OpenID
texts.text: GitHub Actions + OpenID

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most people will generate static authentication credentials, add them as GitHub secrets, and call it a day. That's not for me. I prefer to use OpenID authentication and I avoid putting any credentials into GitHub.
texts.text: Most people will generate static authentication credentials, add them as GitHub secrets, and call it a day. That's not for me. I prefer to use OpenID authentication and I avoid putting any credentials into GitHub.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: How does this process work?
texts.text: How does this process work?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GitHub asks AWS if it can assume a specific role that has permissions to do things at AWS.
texts.text: GitHub asks AWS if it can assume a specific role that has permissions to do things at AWS.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AWS will verify that it's really GitHub making the request and that the request came from a valid source at GitHub.
texts.text: AWS will verify that it's really GitHub making the request and that the request came from a valid source at GitHub.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AWS then provides temporary credentials to GitHub to assume the AWS role and make changes in AWS services.
texts.text: AWS then provides temporary credentials to GitHub to assume the AWS role and make changes in AWS services.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: GitHub has some  great documentation  on this process, but I'll cover it briefly here as well.
texts.text: GitHub has some  great documentation  on this process, but I'll cover it briefly here as well.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We start by making an identity provider at AWS that allows us to trust GitHub as an identity source:
texts.text: We start by making an identity provider at AWS that allows us to trust GitHub as an identity source:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go to the
texts.text: Go to the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Use
texts.text: Use

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Enter
texts.text: Enter

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we need a policy that tells AWS what our GitHub Actions workflow is allowed to do. We use the principle of least privileges to limit access as much as possible:
texts.text: Now we need a policy that tells AWS what our GitHub Actions workflow is allowed to do. We use the principle of least privileges to limit access as much as possible:

texts.text: Click

texts.text: Paste in my template:

texts.text: AWS_ACCOUNT_ID

texts.text: Go back to your CloudFront distribution and use the ID for

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Click  Next , give the policy a friendly name, and finish creating the policy.
texts.text: Click  Next , give the policy a friendly name, and finish creating the policy.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Finally, we need a role that glues these two things together. We tie the role to the identity provider (to allow GitHub to authenticate) and then tie the policy to the role (to allow GitHub Actions to do things in AWS).
texts.text: Finally, we need a role that glues these two things together. We tie the role to the identity provider (to allow GitHub to authenticate) and then tie the policy to the role (to allow GitHub Actions to do things in AWS).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we can create a workflow to build our blog and ship it to S3!
texts.text: Now we can create a workflow to build our blog and ship it to S3!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: GitHub workflow
texts.text: GitHub workflow

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My blog  has a workflow  that might work for you as a starting point. Just in case it disappears, here's an excerpt:
texts.text: My blog  has a workflow  that might work for you as a starting point. Just in case it disappears, here's an excerpt:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
name: Deploy to AWS S3/CloudFront

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - "main"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  id-token: write
  contents: read

concurrency:
  group: "cloudfront"
  cancel-in-progress: true

defaults:
  run:
    shell: bash

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Setup Hugo
        uses: peaceiris/actions-hugo@v2
        with:
          hugo-version: 'latest'
          extended: true

      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          submodules: recursive

      - name: Configure AWS credentials
        uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v1.7.0
        with:
          role-to-assume: arn:aws:iam::911986281031:role/github-actions-major.io-blog
          role-duration-seconds: 900
          aws-region: us-east-1

      - name: Build with Hugo
        env:
          HUGO_ENVIRONMENT: production
          HUGO_ENV: production
        run: hugo --minify

      - name: Deploy to S3
        run: hugo deploy --force --maxDeletes -1 --invalidateCDN
texts.text:
name: Deploy to AWS S3/CloudFront

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - "main"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  id-token: write
  contents: read

concurrency:
  group: "cloudfront"
  cancel-in-progress: true

defaults:
  run:
    shell: bash

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Setup Hugo
        uses: peaceiris/actions-hugo@v2
        with:
          hugo-version: 'latest'
          extended: true

      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          submodules: recursive

      - name: Configure AWS credentials
        uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v1.7.0
        with:
          role-to-assume: arn:aws:iam::911986281031:role/github-actions-major.io-blog
          role-duration-seconds: 900
          aws-region: us-east-1

      - name: Build with Hugo
        env:
          HUGO_ENVIRONMENT: production
          HUGO_ENV: production
        run: hugo --minify

      - name: Deploy to S3
        run: hugo deploy --force --maxDeletes -1 --invalidateCDN

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Reading from top to bottom:
texts.text: Reading from top to bottom:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: We give permissions to write the id token that we get back from AWS and read-only contents to the repo itself.
texts.text: We give permissions to write the id token that we get back from AWS and read-only contents to the repo itself.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Concurrent runs are not allowed (we don't want two updates shipping at the same time).
texts.text: Concurrent runs are not allowed (we don't want two updates shipping at the same time).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The hugo setup and repo checkout are standard for nearly any hugo blog.
texts.text: The hugo setup and repo checkout are standard for nearly any hugo blog.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Next we assume the role at AWS using the ARN of our role that we created in IAM.
texts.text: Next we assume the role at AWS using the ARN of our role that we created in IAM.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Hugo builds the static content as it normally would.
texts.text: Hugo builds the static content as it normally would.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Finally, we deploy new content to the S3 bucket, delete anything that doesn't belong, and we invalidate the CDN cache[^cache_invalidate].
texts.text: Finally, we deploy new content to the S3 bucket, delete anything that doesn't belong, and we invalidate the CDN cache[^cache_invalidate].

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we need to tell hugo  how to deploy  our blog. Open up your blog's configuration file (usually
texts.text: Now we need to tell hugo  how to deploy  our blog. Open up your blog's configuration file (usually

texts.label: code
texts.orig: config.toml
texts.text: config.toml

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ) and add some configuration:
texts.text: ) and add some configuration:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Deployment configuration for S3/CloudFront
[deployment]

[[deployment.targets]]
name = "BLOG_DOMAIN_NAME"
URL = "s3://STATIC_CONTENT_S3_BUCKET?region=AWS_REGION"
cloudFrontDistributionID =	"CLOUDFRONT_DISTRIBUTION"

[[deployment.matchers]]
pattern = "^.+\\.(js|css|png|jpg|gif|svg|ttf)$"
cacheControl = "max-age=2592000, no-transform, public"
gzip = true

[[deployment.matchers]]
pattern = "^.+\\.(html|xml|json)$"
gzip = true
texts.text:
# Deployment configuration for S3/CloudFront
[deployment]

[[deployment.targets]]
name = "BLOG_DOMAIN_NAME"
URL = "s3://STATIC_CONTENT_S3_BUCKET?region=AWS_REGION"
cloudFrontDistributionID =	"CLOUDFRONT_DISTRIBUTION"

[[deployment.matchers]]
pattern = "^.+\\.(js|css|png|jpg|gif|svg|ttf)$"
cacheControl = "max-age=2592000, no-transform, public"
gzip = true

[[deployment.matchers]]
pattern = "^.+\\.(html|xml|json)$"
gzip = true

texts.label: title
texts.orig: DNS
texts.text: DNS

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sending visitors to your new site in CloudFront is one DNS record away!
texts.text: Sending visitors to your new site in CloudFront is one DNS record away!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Go back to the list of CloudFront distributions in your AWS console and click on the one you created earlier. Look for the  Distribution domain name  at the top left and you should see a domain that looks like
texts.text: Go back to the list of CloudFront distributions in your AWS console and click on the one you created earlier. Look for the  Distribution domain name  at the top left and you should see a domain that looks like

texts.label: code

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Summary
texts.text: Summary

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In this  lengthy  post, we did plenty of things:
texts.text: In this  lengthy  post, we did plenty of things:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 🪣  Configured S3 buckets to hold our static blog content and CDN logs
texts.text: 🪣  Configured S3 buckets to hold our static blog content and CDN logs

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 🚀  Deployed a CloudFront distribution to serve our content quickly to visitors around the world
texts.text: 🚀  Deployed a CloudFront distribution to serve our content quickly to visitors around the world

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 🔑  Built IAM roles and policies to avoid placing any sensitive credentials in our GitHub repository
texts.text: 🔑  Built IAM roles and policies to avoid placing any sensitive credentials in our GitHub repository

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 🔧  Re-configured hugo to deploy content directly to S3 and flush the CDN cache
texts.text: 🔧  Re-configured hugo to deploy content directly to S3 and flush the CDN cache

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 🚚  Assembled a GitHub workflow to build the static content and ship it to S3
texts.text: 🚚  Assembled a GitHub workflow to build the static content and ship it to S3

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I love learning new things and this is one of many that I've enjoyed. Hopefully you enjoyed it, too! 💕
texts.text: I love learning new things and this is one of many that I've enjoyed. Hopefully you enjoyed it, too! 💕

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^spoiler]: Spoiler alert! This blog is already on AWS S3 and CloudFront as of today. 😉
texts.text: [^spoiler]: Spoiler alert! This blog is already on AWS S3 and CloudFront as of today. 😉

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^s3extras]: Yes, there are some charges for requests, but these charges are so small, you're likely not to notice. Putting a CDN out front greatly reduces those requests even further since origin requests to S3 will only happen for cache misses. 1M requests to S3 comes out to about $5 per month and that's orders of magnitude more than I can use.
texts.text: [^s3extras]: Yes, there are some charges for requests, but these charges are so small, you're likely not to notice. Putting a CDN out front greatly reduces those requests even further since origin requests to S3 will only happen for cache misses. 1M requests to S3 comes out to about $5 per month and that's orders of magnitude more than I can use.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^cache_invalidate]: Invalidating the cache is not required, but it does help with getting new content served by the CDN as soon after a deployment as possible.
texts.text: [^cache_invalidate]: Invalidating the cache is not required, but it does help with getting new content served by the CDN as soon after a deployment as possible.
